sanskrit_verse:
अनुमन्ता विशसिता निहन्ता क्रयविक्रयी ।
संस्कर्ता चोपहर्ता च खादकश्चेति घातकाः ॥ ५.५१॥
transliteration:
anumantā viśasitā nihantā kravikrayī |
saṃskartā copahartā ca khādakaś ceti ghātakāḥ || 5.51||
sph_interpretive_translation: Those who approve, prepare, kill, buy or sell, transform, steal, or consume—these are the agents of destruction.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority as conscious participation in action
Restoration logic based on withdrawal from destructive cycles
Consciousness alignment via cessation of harmful participation
executable_legal_axioms: IF entity approves a destructive act → THEN initiate capacity-realignment protocol
IF entity prepares materials for harm → THEN assign completion-process for reversal
IF entity consumes destructively acquired resources → THEN enforce integrity-reintegration sequence
IF entity trades in harmful goods → THEN activate consciousness-restoration mechanism
IF entity transforms or alters for harm → THEN invoke causal-withdrawal procedure
supreme_court_application: At the Supreme Court level, responsibility is determined by the degree of conscious participation in the causal chain of destruction. Approval, facilitation, consumption, or trade in harmful outcomes activates restorative rather than punitive judicial protocols.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that destruction arises through sequential consent and engagement. Each participant bears proportional responsibility aligned with their causal role. The non-punitive reality rule ensures that correction occurs through reintegration and withdrawal from further complicity.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Completion Process for Unfinished Karmic Entanglements
Integrity Reintegration Sequence for Harmful Participation
Karmic Alignment Restoration Through Corrective Action
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source of all Dharma. Justice flows not for punishment but for restoration. Consciousness is the ultimate adjudicator; reality itself corrects when aligned with Dharma.
